fact_list.fact_text: It is an offence to use mobile communication devices, including mobile telephones and handheld devices designed for communicative functions, while driving.
Should you need to use a mobile communication device while driving, you should drive to a safe place such as a carpark and use it when stationary.

Communicative functions of mobile communication devices refer to functions such as sending or receiving oral or written messages, electronic documents, still or moving images, audio or video files, and accessing the internet.
Any driver caught using a mobile communication device whilst driving will be charged in court.
The penalty for using a mobile communication device while driving is a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months, or both.
An offender's driving licence is likely to be disqualified if caught using a mobile communication device while driving.
Typical scenarios of using mobile communication devices while driving include driving with one hand holding a device, texting, dialling a phone number, or pressing a button to receive a call.
Using hands-free devices is acceptable unless the driver is holding onto the mobile communication device while the vehicle is in motion.
A driver commits an offence if they meet these three conditions: holding a mobile communication device with at least one hand, using any function of the device, and the motor vehicle is in motion.
